feed.title: MSC Technical Information
feed.subtitle: A blog of updates, documentation, and information for tehcnology and operations for the Movement Strategy Center.

entry.title: Known Issues with Hub Network
entry.content:
At this time, UDP traffic and dcsp marking for Zoom has been implemented. And for the unified wireless network, the AP throughout the hub are kept rolling on updates and auto channels within different subnets in an attempt to provide benefits of a unified wide area network, well controlling cross talk and congestion.

Still, there are some known problems that persist with the network despite steps taken to fix.

  • printing a Google Drive document from Chrome, resulting in ERROR 600
    • possible fix:
      • update printer driver
      • print to different printer
      • possibly document contains fonts not recognized by Google
  • video conferencing on wireless network–connection dropped
    • possible fix:
      • using thunderbolt (MAC), or USB adapter for ethernet
      • quitting all active and background applications before session
  • channel congestion from other AP within building typically on ch. 1, 6-7, & 11
    • possible fix:
      • set AP to auto, during high congestion
      • monitor other known AP common channels and avoid if possible
      • install/convert APs to 2-5ghz (higher frequency less congestion)
  • some broadcast traffic (systems, share-points, smartwatches, phones, tablets…)
    • possible fix:
      • turning off sharing services for systems and devices that are property of MSC
      • sub-netting
  • increased congestion with meetings and gatherings, resulting in poor connectivity
    • possible fix:
      • sub-netting
      • install 5ghz AP
  • poor connectivity behind closed door offices
    • possible fix:
      • install AP in office
      • install switch in office for ethernet
  • VLAN 2 (public network) accessed by clients w/ limited bandwidth
    • possible fix:
      • switch VLAN 2 ports to VLAN 3
      • take VLAN 2 ports down
  • use of CAT 5 cables and cable fraying, degradation
    • possible fix:
      • cleanup network rack, switch to CAT 6
      • extend CAT cable AP, no longer use cables with punched keystones
  • microwave operating in proximity of the AP
    • possible fix:
      • move AP farther away
  • MB Air poor connectivity when memory pressure is high
    • possible fix:
      • limit use of services/applications with large memory footprint
      • insist usage of ethernet adapter
      • keep system os updated
entry.summary: At this time, UDP traffic and dcsp marking for Zoom has been implemented. And for the unified wireless network, the AP throughout the hub are kept rolling on updates and auto channels within different subnets in an attempt to provide benefits of a unified wide area network, well controlling cross talk and congestion.

entry.title: Using Team Drive
entry.content:
Team Drive has been enabled and I see a handful of you already using it. I needed to enable the whole domain in order to test functionality with some other services… Its a fairly new feature that may be informed by some best practices for Google Drive usage in this draft here.

Somethings to note with Team Drive for those whom have interest and/or already using: Team Drives do not synch/appear in Google Desktop client; i.e. no path appears in Finder/File Explorer Recommending either making NEW files/folders for your Team Drive, or copy TOP folder from My Drive, then move to Team Drive Moving files in bulk from My Drive to Team Drive may result in data loss (I can help recover on request). That said, the functionality of Team Drives is more akin to a true file server and an improvement. You can find more information on Team Drives for Google here.

Reminder: If you are planning on creating a Team Drive, please feel free to contact me for assistance

Because of the aforementioned, I’m waiting for an update that expands the API for the service which I don’t think will happen until beginning of 2018 before using Team Drive. Yet I realize there is a need, so have made the feature available.
entry.summary: Team Drive has been enabled and I see a handful of you already using it. I needed to enable the whole domain in order to test functionality with some other services… Its a fairly new feature that may be informed by some best practices for Google Drive usage in this draft here.

entry.title: Best Practices for File Sharing
entry.content:
File/Folder Naming Problem?

This document is to provide some best practices for file naming and storage policies. Project members, departments and individuals can establish folder and file naming conventions, guiding their teams to actions all can sustainably follow, so their files are managed better. Experiencing results like unpredictable filing, confusing/varying naming, duplication, and loss can be remedied through the following practices.

General File Naming Best Practices

The most important things to remember about file naming are to be consistent and plainly descriptive in naming and organizing your files. The goal is that it’s obvious where to find a file and what it contains.

Information to consider including in file names:

  1. Project or experiment name or acronym
  2. Location/spatial coordinates/identifiers
  3. Staff name/initials
  4. Date or date range of project
  5. Type of data
  6. Conditions
  7. Version number/tag of file
  8. file extension for application specific files

These are only suggestions; include whatever infor will allow you to distinguish your files from each other and clearly indicate to you what is in them.

Other tips for file naming:

  1. A good format for dates is YYYYMMDD (or YYMMDD); this makes sure all your files stay in chronological order, even over many years.
  2. Don’t make file names too long; longer names do not work well with all types of software.
  3. Special characters should be avoided; e.g. ~!@#$%^&*()`;<>?,[]{}‘“
  4. For sequential numbering, use leading zeros to ensure files sort properly; e.g. use “0001, 0002…1001, etc” instead of “1, 2…1001, etc.”
  5. Do not use spaces, because they are not recognized by some software, instead use:
    • underscores (file_name.xxx),
    • dashes (file-name.xxx),
    • no separation (filename.xxx),
    • camel case (FileName.xxx)

Renaming files

You may already have a lot of data collected for your project and wish to organize and rename these files for easier management. There are ways to batch rename with Windows or Mac OSX (select all, right click > Rename is often the simplest way, remember Edit > Undo) but if you have too many files to rename them all by hand, make a copy of source folder/files, then with a copy try one of the following applications for renaming your files:

Bulk Rename Utility (Windows, free) FileRename (Windows, Mac, free/paid) Rename4u (Windows, free) Renamer 4 (Mac–Single, Family pack) PSRenamer (Linux, Mac, or Windows, free)

Naming Convention ‐ Solution Planning

Any effort to institute file / folder naming and storage policies may be initiated by anyone in an organization. Following the aforementioned may help, yet to ensure success it is extremely important that such policies be heralded by a lead and/or stakeholder.

**Stakeholders and leads have the authority to instill and communicate that files: **

  • are information assets that are the property of the organization.
  • are shareable resources although sometimes for restricted users only.
  • are critical components to operations that affect productivity and profitability.

Execution

Once the file naming and storage conventions are finalized, they should be documented and made available to all, to reference and follow, within top folders of a directory–e.g. perhaps, part of a “README.txt” file. Edits to these documents should be announced so all are knowledgeable of any changes.

entry.title: Accessing Online Organizational Accounts
entry.content:
Access to online organizational accounts can be located via the Egnyte file server.

Three excel workbooks hold credentials which are used to login and initiate various services for the organization. To receive the password for those documents please contact IT/Ops or ask a team member for access.

Never share credentials via unencrypted email or over an social networking platform.

Credentials are tiered, with master passes held in Admin_Pass.xls. If not editing please open as Read-Only file. Please upload any edits ASAP to avoid any possible discrepancies

Name/Linked Description Path
Admin_pass.xlsx all online org acct. incl. other workbook passes Shared>Operations Team>Usernames
Usernames.xlsx general org operational accounts Shared>Operations Team>Usernames
Finance_Usernames.xlsx online financial, personnel accounts Shared>Finance Team>Usernames
entry.summary: Access to online organizational accounts can be located via the Egnyte file server.

entry.title: Best Practices for Digital Receipts
entry.content:
Overview

In general, submission of digital receipts should follow department policy.

  • Itemized receipt
  • Shows at least last 4 of cc#
  • Tickets/vouchers with payment details, not just travel itineraries
  • Transaction matches statement record…etc
  • Scanned Receipts

Problems:

  • Image Orientation: card-holders may scans that are crooked, hard to reprint
  • Image Resolution: card-holders may send scans that are blurry, unreadable; may send “receipt quilts” or collection of receipts that are hard to interpret
  • File size: card-holders may send scans (files) that are large and hard to download, move, etc.
  • File type: card-holders may send scans that differ in file-type, making it hard to narrow queries, read, edit, etc.
  • File Naming: card holders may send scans that follow no naming conventions, making it hard to query, organize, etc.

Recommendations:

  • REJECT: Camera photos outright – pic looks to be in perspective, tilted, NOT FLAT
  • Flat-bed scans preferred: card-holders should be directed to using a “flat-bed” scanner to capture their receipts, ensuring clear resolution
  • Portable Wand Scans - accepted, perhaps suggested for highly mobile staff??
  • Smart-phone “scans” accepted, not encouraged
  • Single receipt per image: card-holder sends a scan for each receipt, so identification of expense is clear, easily name file for archiving
  • Only >25MB scans: file sent below 25MB are easy to work with, transmit over email, migrate to cloud, etc
  • Preferred B&W scans: files in color are typically larger (see above)
  • NO GIFs NO TIFs: prefer small PNGs, .JPGs, and/or small PDFs, ensures good resolution, no artifacts
  • Watch out for fax/zerox conversions - may create artifacts, poor resolution
  • Watch out for small unclear .JPGs - artifacts, poor resolution, easy to “manufacture”
  • Create Naming Conventions: recommend statement period and vendor name and # only
    • Eg: 0915Starbucks1

E-Receipts

Problems:

  • Proliferation of services: each card-holder may choose a different service, w/ own style of production and retrieval, meaning:
  • Managing and communicating an assortment of credentials
  • Unknown repositories, little uniform collection
  • Threshold on production: typically e-receipts are only produced on transactions below $75, meaning:
  • Directions to card-holder on splitting the purchase into increments
  • Consistent followup on outliers, failures, etc.
  • Credit Card Type:
  • Commercial Credit Cards - (FirstBank Card) difficult to configure/setup in many expense management applications
  • Corporate Credit Cards - (Capitol One Card) at MSC this is setup under Taj as umbrella account, making integration (breaking out) in expense management applications a bit clunky

Recommendation:

  • One Type: consider using one “type” of Credit Card as a department to capture in expense management app
  • Survey: ask Card-holders for preferred expense management app IF rolling in retrieval as part of task/service of department
  • Encourage email filters: Mail filters to auto-fwd expense 75$>
  • Create filters in card-holder accounts against “no-reply” addresses for square, google play, apple pay, and various travel vendors
  • Recommend regardless of amount
entry.summary: Overview In general, submission of digital receipts should follow department policy.

entry.title: Supply Order Policy
entry.content:
Operations’ goal with supply ordering is to sustain and monitor a supply of regular office items for use by MSC staff and community. Some guidelines need to be followed to achieve this.

Guidelines:

  • All purchases over $500 should be approved by the Finance Director or the Managing Director
  • Supply orders for Projects/events should be communicated before hand, accordingly purchased and allocated

  • Supplies are stored:

    • Supply Cabinets

    • Data Room cabinets

    • Playroom Shelving

    • Call Room shelving

  • Any supply order request should be written down by MSC staff using the Supply list posted on the Main supply cabinet

  • Shared Items for community use are:

  • Copier Paper (for Suite printers)

  • Tape (for data room)

  • Klennex

  • White board erasers

  • White board markers

Vendors

MSC purchases supplies with the following vendors (credentials can be found in the “usernames” document:

Vendor Item(s) type Purchaser(s) Frequency ——————————————————————————————————————————————- ————————————————————————————————- ———————- ———————-

Vendor Items Purchaser Frequency                
Amazon (www.amazon.com) devices, hardware, peripherals, furniture, tools, toner cartridges, misc. minor office supplies Operations; Projects Monthly; as needed                
Better Life (www.cleanhappens.com/collections/bulk-cleaning-products) Bulk kitchen & restroom cleaning products, supplies Operations Quarterly; as needed Craigslist (www.craigslist.org) Furniture Operations as needed Give Something Back (givesomethingback.com) General office items: paper, pencils, tape, paper clips etc. Operations Weekly
Grove Tools (http://www.grove.com/site/ourwk_prods.html) facilitation supplies Projects as needed Uline (uline.com) shipping packaging; storage Operations as needed        

Guidelines:

  • Make purchases from GSB on a weekly basis

  • Refer to the Supply List on the supply cabinet before purchasing

  • Check stock (including back stock) on a monthly basis to maintain adequate supplies

  • Purchase generic (Universal) brand for bulk items

    • pens

    • signature flags

    • paper clips

    • binder clips

    • tape

    • staples

  • Shared Supplies
entry.summary: Operations’ goal with supply ordering is to sustain and monitor a supply of regular office items for use by MSC staff and community. Some guidelines need to be followed to achieve this.
